source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Basal (0002) and prism {1010} pole figures for Zircaloy-2 tubing produced by different fabrication methods were determined after extrusion and final reduction on several layers of the tube wal.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Basal (0002) and prism {1010} pole figures for Zircaloy-2 tubing produced by different fabrication methods were determined after extrusion and final reduction on several layers of the tube wal.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: For various processing conditions, markedly different textures as well as significant texture gradients across the wall thickness were found.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: A concentration of basal poles toward the radial direction occurred if there was a preponderance of reduction in wall thickness.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: A split of basal poles toward the tangential direction occurred if there was a preponderance of reduction in diameter.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The ingot analysis gave an average chemical composition (weight percentage) over the bar length of 1.6 Sn, 0.14 Fe, 0.085 Cr, and 0.05 Ni

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The forged bar was extruded to 76-mm outside diameter at 760 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The foils used for the transmission measurements were obtained by further chemical thinning of the reflection specimens. The thickness of the foils here corresponded to 2 to 3 times the half-value thickness for $\mathrm { { C u } } ~ \mathrm { { K } } \alpha$ .

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The portions of the pole figures determined by the reflection technique are quantitative, because the measured intensities were related to the intensities of a Zr-powder specimen with random orientation. However, those portions completed by transmission are only qualitative (dashed lines in the pole figures).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Additional measurements of the basal plane intensities in the RD were made as a function of position on the tube circumference. These proved that there was no circumferential texture variation in these tubes.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The basal-pole figure (Fig. 2) of the extrusion with low ratio of wall-todiameter reduction (9C) shows that the preferred position of basal poles in this material is at a very high angle in the RD-TD plane (near the TD).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The intensity maxima increase from the inner ( $1 0 \times$ random) to the outer $( > 1 6 ~ \times$ random) surfaces.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The angle at which the basal-pole intensity is a maximum $\psi$ , measured in the RD-TD plane with $\mathbf { R D } = 0$ deg and $\mathrm { T D } = 9 0$ deg)also increases from $\psi = \pm 5 0$ to 90 deg from the inner to the outer surface.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: As the reduction in diameter $( R _ { D } )$ decreases and the reduction in wall thickness $( R _ { W } )$ increases (10C), $\psi$ becomes smaller (Fig. 3).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The split angle, $\boldsymbol { \zeta }$ , which gives the inclination of the preferred positions of basal poles from the RD toward the AD, is constant over the wall thickness and has a range of $\pm 5$ to 7 deg.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The prism-pole figure also shows a split for the preferred position of { 1010} planes. Here, however, the split angle lies in the range of 30 deg.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Textures measured at various depths in the wall show a slight decrease in intensity maxima from the inner to the outer surface (11 to $9 ~ \times$ random), whereas $\psi$ increases slightly in the same direction $( \mathrm { f r o m } \pm 4 5 $ to 50 deg).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Textures measured at various depths in the wall show a slight decrease in intensity maxima from the inner to the outer surface (11 to $9 ~ \times$ random), whereas $\psi$ increases slightly in the same direction $( \mathrm { f r o m } \pm 4 5 $ to 50 deg).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Material with a still higher ratio of wall-to-diameter reduction (11C) gives qualitatively the same texture (Fig. 4) as 10C.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Textures measured across the wall thickness show only a slight decrease of intensity maxima from the inner to the outer surface (11 to about $1 0 ~ \times$ random).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The position of maximum intensity lies in the range of $\downarrow = \pm 4 2$ to 46 deg with no significant gradient over the wall thickness.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The split angle $\boldsymbol { \xi }$ is slightly increased and now lies in the range of $\xi = \pm 7$ to 9 deg.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The results vary from $\psi = \pm 4 0$ to 90 deg for different processing conditions.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: High $R _ { W }$ and low $R _ { D }$ , for a constant ${ \pmb R } _ { A }$ , cause a shift of the preferred position of basal poles toward the center of the pole figure (up to an angle of $\psi = \pm 4 0$ deg).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: For the ball-swaged tube with a high ratio of wall-to-diameter reduction (Fig. 5), the basal-plane pole figure as well as the prism-plane pole figure are slightly asymmetric. The single basal maximum of $1 3 . 3 \ \times$ random is tilted from the RD toward the TD at an angle of $\psi = + 9$ deg.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The single basal maximum of $1 3 . 3 \ \times$ random is tilted from the RD toward the TD at an angle of $\psi = + 9$ deg.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: For the tube-reduced material with medium ratio of wall-to-diameter reduction (Fig. 6) basal- and prism-plane pole figures are asymmetric as in tube 9W. However, here are two (0002) maxima.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: the preferred position of basal poles is split at an angle of about $\pm 5 5$ deg toward the TD, when $R _ { D }$ is dominant. The maximum intensity is about $8 . 5 ~ \times$ random.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The maximum intensity is about $8 . 5 ~ \times$ random.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: For the ball swaged tube, 9W (Fig. 8), processed with high $R _ { W }$ , the (0002) plane pole figures taken on foils in steps of $0 . 0 5 \mathrm { m m }$ through the wall thickness vary markedly.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: Going from the inner to the outer surface, $\psi$ for the left peak is in the range $^ { - 2 2 }$ to $^ { - 2 8 }$ deg and $\psi$ for the right intensity maximum is rather constant at $+ 3 1$ deg.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: $\psi$ for the right intensity maximum is rather constant at $+ 3 1$ deg.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The intensity is about $1 0 ~ \times$ random for both peaks.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: the maximum intensity here is about $1 4 \times$ random intensity.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: Texture development is similar in the tubing (10w), tube-reduced with a preponderance of $R _ { W }$ (Fig. 9). The basal-pole tilts at the inner part of the tube wall are rather constant and are $\psi = - 2 7$ deg for the left peak and $\psi = + 3 1$ deg for the right peak.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: $\psi = + 3 1$ deg for the right peak.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The maximum intensity is nearly $1 0 ~ \times$ random for both.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The maximum intensity of tube $1 0 \mathbf { W }$ , tube-reduced, is higher than that in the ball-swaged tube (9W) and is in the range 14 to $1 8 ~ \times$ random.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: material tube-reduced with a preponderance of $R _ { D }$ (11W) shows no significant change of (0002) texture over the wall thickness (Fig. 10).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The average intensity height is about $9 . 4 ~ \times$ random.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The tilt of basal-pole maxima is in the range $\psi = \pm 5 3$ to 63 deg.

evidence_span: tube reducing with predominant $R _ { W }$ (tube 10W) produces a strong texture gradient through the wall thickness

evidence_span: tube 9W was ball-swaged in six passes

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: A preponderance of reduction in wall thickness promotes a texture with basal poles parallel to the radial direction

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: A preponderance of reduction in diameter leads to a split of basal poles toward the tangential direction with a tilt angle of about $\pm 5 5$ deg

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: A preponderance of reduction in wall thickness may also cause a texture gradient through the wall tube

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: This does not appear in tube reducing with predominant reduction in diameter

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Essentially similar textures are developed by ball swaging and tube reduction when both processes are done with a preponderance of reduction in wall thickness

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_007_chunk5
evidence_span: In alpha-phase zirconium alloys (close-packed hexagonal structure), anisotropic deformation of individual grains combined with crystallographic texture almost always present in fabricated products introduces an additional complication into the ductility measurement
